reviews.review_title: An E-type hearse and a zest for life
reviews.content: Harold and Maude rates highly in any film connoisseur's list as, perhaps, the black comedy of all time. The film was released in 1971 and has a superb cast, lead by Ruth Gordon (who won and Oscar for her role in Rosemary's Baby in 1968) as the 79-year-old Maude, and Bud Cort (Romero in Coyote Ugly) as the 20-year-old Harold.Harold is a rich kid, who craves attention from his mother, but only gets it when he fakes his own suicide. Discovering the power of death, his curiosity takes him to the funeral of someone he doesn't know. His fascination leads him to more funerals, where he sees Maude and realises that she, too, is an uninvited guest.Harold doesn't have much of a life; he has left school, but doesn't know what to do with his future. His mother lives in a social whirl and isn't very interested in him  apart from her aim to find him a wife and get him off her hands.Maude is a dear old lady, with real vitality and a zest for life; she wants to cram in as much as she can before the Grim Reaper knocks on her door! From the day they meet, Harold and Maude become inseparable. She has so much to teach him about life, and he has so much to learn.On his journey of self-knowledge, Maude helps him as no person ever has done before. The film has some excellent humour and comedy lines, bordering on slapstick that hit the nail on the head every time.As the relationship between these two eccentric souls strengthens, Harold's personality and self-respect grows, whilst his mother, even more worried by his affection for an old lady, goes to all lengths to save him  even buying him an E-Type Jaguar (which he converts into an E-Type hearse).This black comedy is not all black. It has a certain feel-good factor about it and it is incredibly funny. There are elements of suspense, romance and intrigue, as well as a large portion of satire.The opening sequence will make you wonder if you really want to watch the rest of the film, but after the first few minutes you will not feel so uncomfortable and will be gripped by the storyline that will not release you until the credits come up at the end. And what an end it is!Ironically, the soundtrack music is by Cat Stevens; surprisingly, it doesn't feel out of place, and it helps to bring the 70's ambiance to the screen.There are so few films around these days that do not insult your intelligence, if you get a chance to see Harold and Maude you really should. And if you can, take a very close friend so that you are both guaranteed a shoulder to cry on.

This film simply does not hold up one bit.  The performances are very bland and entirely meaningless.  The only character that is even remotely enjoyable is Vivian Pickles as 'Harold's' Mother.  Ruth Gordon falls flat on her face and Bud Cort is essentially being himself.  The only other truly positive thing about this film, other than Vivian Pickles, is the excellent musical score by Cat Stevens.I find it extremely difficult to believe that there was any real love that existed between these two characters.  The humor is clearly speaking to a specific generation, and often fails to be effective.  I haven't much else too add, other than the fact that this film is pretty much a waste of time.

On the plus side of this film, the 2 characters were both likeable, 3 infact if you count the mother who probably was the pick of the lot & the roles were acted well. I wouldn't call this a laughing out loud film, for me personally, but there were a handful of amusing scenes throughout. I would definitely go along with the people who call this a feel good film. It is. Sadly though, I didn't think it was a great film.It struck me as one of the most American films I've ever seen. Nothing wrong with that, but some of the jokes & the satire weren't meant specifically for a world wide audience. Some of the jokes like Maude's driving & eccentricity & the suicide attempts were amusing initially, but drummed home a little too much by the end that they got dull. There was also a little too much Cat Stevens for me, though the final tune was a good one.A high 5/10.
Quirky, funny masterpiece. One of my faves. Don't miss it!

If ever you wondered about the meaning of life and inevitability of death, this is a movie that can give a few hints. 
I thoroughly enjoyed the originality and apparent relaxed ease and fun in this production.

"Harold and Maude" is one of the few films that I have had the privilege to see "cold" without any prior knowledge of or opinions about the film before having seen it. I fell in love with the movie after the first few minutes, and I have loved it ever since. Although it is obviously a product of the 60's/70's, its message is clear, simple, and still relevant: "Live life to the fullest, one day at a time, and don't sweat the small stuff." Harold and Maude may have been outrageously eccentric characters (even for the 60's/70's), but deep down they are two of the most genuine characters ever projected onto the big screen. The movie and its characters can only be described as "funky," but in a very natural and entirely unself-conscious way. Actually, the movie's eccentricity is its most remarkable and endearing quality; I don't think that anybody will ever be stupid enough to try to imitate it or (God forbid!) "remake" it. Obviously, it is high on the list of my ten favorite movies.

reviews.review_title: Movie-making the way it should be.
reviews.content: After hearing various references to this movie throughout my life I finally rented it this weekend. I thought that something fresh was needed given the never-ending crop of crap emanating from Hollywood for the last several years.Getting to the point...I loved it. I loved it so much, I immediately watched it again. (I hadn't done something like that since I was a small kid in the public movie theater).If you haven't seen this movie, and you are not one of the current loud-mouthed individuals in the world who has a terminal case of cranium-rectal insertion, you'll love it! Take 91 minutes and do your mind a favor...set it free and enjoy the ride! Bravo! P.S. Hollywood...Hands off! Any attempt to remake this movie would only ruin it.

I have a thing for odd couples, and have written a couple of stories about such pairings.  The gap in age in HAROLD AND MAUDE is made more acceptable, I think, because of the comic treatment.Harold is put off by girls his own age, who lack the gravitas that he has come to associate with death.  A peculiar taste, and a morbid one, but one shared by Maude--perhaps with more reason.Strange as this film is, I don't think it compares in strangeness with the one about the necrophiliac girl who works in a funeral parlor--I forget the title.HAROLD AND MAUDE is a movie I would recommend to anyone with a taste for dark or warped humor, and anyone interested in offbeat romances.

One of my top ten favourite films. Just like The Wizard of Oz and It's a Wonderful life, this movie was not well received at the time by many critics and did only adequately well at the box office. Although it will never have the broad appeal of those films, time has proven it to be a classic and it will probably endure long after many more critically acclaimed features fade from memory.

This was one of those movies that I *wanted* to like, but I really did not. Harold was pretty well done, but I thought the character of Maude was kind of cliché - the spunky, non-law-abiding old lady with free-love tendencies. I was sort of irritated by how perfect/idealistic she was.On the positive side - I did see some important themes in this film that go beyond its hippie appearance. The final sequence was great, and a very effective bookend to the rest of the movie.It was Maude that detracted from the movie's potential power. She was such an absurd character, I couldn't get far enough past that to really appreciate this movie. It has a really good soundtrack, though.

Turner Classic Movies is currently showing this, perhaps due to the 35th anniversary, perhaps not. Regardless, I saw this in a theater when it was new, and is making me feel old. But that is the only part of this movie that makes me feel old! The plot is refreshing to both mind and the spirit. What is really interesting to me is how the movie seems to be in that "in-between" period of 1960's conservative family values and 1970's more liberal, experimental type films. It really does feel like 1971. Excellent performances from all, and good action scenes in a movie that really is a non-action movie! Cat Stevens soundtrack helps define the story, and to this day when I hear Cat Stevens music, I think of this film. That is what a soundtrack is supposed to do, and it scores!

I have to class this as a lost classic. I have only ever seen H&M once before on late night BBC2 TV in the UK in the 1980's. I remember loving it then but great news it is now available in the UK on DVD.What can I say about this film other than its simply wonderful. Funny, touching, great music, great story. There is just so much to be gained from watching this film.As for the acting. I think that Bud Cort and Ruth Gordon were mesmeric. The way she looks at him at times makes you think she was really coming onto him. And when she drops the bombshell at the end and he starts to shout...great editing.And I just love the Jag hearse.A film that should never ever be remade...ever.If you want to live high live high eh!

What does it mean to live in a neurotic, disconnected world where the people in our lives who should care the most ... don't?That's Harold's reality. And he has a solution: death. Maybe one more death will get Mom to finally care. But of course, she doesn't. "Do try to be a little more vivacious, Harold!"By the way, the movie never answers the question: Are these suicides fake? We don't know. All we know is he kills himself, and he keeps on living. At that moment when his eyes turn to the camera, we think we know. But do we?The comedy and tragedy of the movie is Harold and his mother each trying to figure out what to do about the other's existence. Mom tries to fix him, but all of her "repairs" go awry. Harold tries to get her to understand, but she cannot. They live on different planets.And, yes, the scene where Mom answers the computer dating questions-it is one of the funniest scenes ever performed.What is Maude? Maude is Harold's attempt to find someone who will listen, someone who will care. But does she? Ultimately, no, for Harold and Maude live on different planets also. In fact, every character in this entire gem of a film occupies a separate universe.So, no, the movie is not intended to teach us moral lessons about stealing cars or twenty year olds hooking up with 80 year olds. But it does give us a second look at ourselves-vulnerable people living in a mixed up world.

The plot of this movie is upsetting to some I have talked to. Some people can't get past the idea of a young man dating an 80 year old woman. If you can see past that, this movie will make you laugh cry and even stop to think occasionally. It is as far out as World according to Garp (another truly great offbeat character study) as funny as Ghostbusters and as tragic as Leaving Las Vegas. The characters are delightfully wacky and the story even more so. It makes a great movie to pop in your DVD changer ahead of the more serious "sex, lies, and videotape" as the ending of H&M thematically links with sex's opening, and both stories deal with unconventional characters searching for love and an understanding of the world around them. If you can't find it in your heart to love this movie... well then maybe you don't have a heart.

reviews.review_title: I just didn't get this film
reviews.content: I've always been one to think outside the box by default. The scene in Young Frankenstein where Marty Feldman selects the 'Abby normal' brain has always resonated with me so I guess I'm just a plain old weirdo. My take away from this odd film after seeing the final scene was that the Harold character was a litterbug. I found the self-centered actions of Maude to be selfish and just plain rude. Imagine if everyone acted this way. If she revered life so much why choose to end it?

reviews.review_title: Aside from Gordon's acting, this is mediocre
reviews.content:
I wanted to test the "rave reviews" against my instincts. Well, as usual, instinct wins.Here's my breakdown:STORY:
Since I'm on the verge of a rant here, I'll relax, breathe slowly ... and here's my rant:
1. This story is an archetype of the 60's and 70's, e.g. Pompous treatment of suicide, pretense, excess, etc.2. I'm sick of wealthy, erudite snobs using film to spew drivel - because the money and hollow praise is there.3. While this could have been done well, it's botched.ACTING:
Ruth Gordon was an awesome actress, but that's it. The rest of the cast are just taking up space.ENTERTAINMENT:
Low - moderate valueTEMPO:
Overall OK, but the beginning ... ughCINEMATOGRAPHY:
Ashby had very good camera skills - but that's itMUSIC / SOUND:
OKDIRECTING / WRITING:
Director: After watching "Being There" (1979) and this, I've put Ashby under the "directors to avoid" category.Writers: Higgins only wrote for nine (9) films, all save one was fun "Foul Play" (1978) ... but I can't stand Chase.Nonetheless, his other work was more TV ish.Is it a good film? Passable, but not for meShould you watch this once? NoRating: 6.5 (for Gordon)

reviews.review_title: A deeply black comedy with a serious message and hilariously shocking scenes!
reviews.content: I first saw Harold and Maude as a teenager in the early eighties and, even then, was moved by the moral of the tale... celebrate life while you can, don't dwell on impending death - however near or far it may be. What puts this film above any other morality tale, however, is the side-splittingly funny way it gets this message across.The scenes where Bud Cort's mother introduces him to potential partners only to have them scared away when he commits 'suicide' are some of the funniest I have ever witnessed on celluloid.The 'affair' between Bud and Ruth Gordon imparts another underlying theme of inter-generational love and does so in a tender and sensitive manner.The finale serves to drive home the message so well that this film rose to and has, for nearly twenty years since, endured as my personal favourite movie of all time.

reviews.review_title: It will change the way you think.
reviews.content:
contain spoilers...I honestly never know what I'll write.Harold and Maude is a difficult movie to reduce to words. It is much easier to simply watch this masterpiece and reach its end- only to discover that you've witnessed something that touches deeper than you may yet know.Essentially, it is a story about Harold (Bud Cort- literally a one-movie phenomenon for no explicable reason...) and his personal journey from wanting nothing more than to die, to living life with every fiber of his being. It is a very personal, enlightening journey (albeit hysterical, as well) thanks to the guidance of Maude (Ruth Gordon- absolutely brilliantly cast), a 79 year-old with a pension for trying "something new each day". The world could due to take a page or two from Maude's book- her advice, ranging from the cure to individual sorrow to religion, is without peer.
The screenplay is so wickedly well done, and the directing is so perfectly suited to the material, that oftentimes, the actor's facial expressions carry whole conversations. (Bud Cort, case in point- especially the "Mona Lisa smile" after his faked immolation).The movie is life-affirming without whacking you over the head with ideals and morals. There's something to be said for subtlety in the ideas a movie is trying to express-Harold and Maude makes it look effortless. In the final analysis- while I can plainly see how this movie isn't for everyone (jabbing a finger in the eye of the military and religion) for those with enough open mind left- it is an experience you will never forget.

Usually with my favorite films (like this one) I want to talk about why I love it. But I feel the need to address some of the comments of other posters this time. Just because Harold is a spoiled rich kid, doesn't mean he doesn't need Maude's help. Did it ever occur to anyone that by helping Harold realize what life has to offer, that he might go on to help others and fight for worthwhile causes, like Maude herself did? Also, I think the criticism of flashing Maude's concentration camp number is misguided at best. I'm reminded of Martin Scorcese relating how his experiences in Little Italy shaped him. Her concentration camp experience obviously shaped her, but if they had been the only experiences that shaped her, this movie probably would have been a lot more like Rod Steiger in "The Pawnbroker" So just enjoy the wit and wisdom that Maude imparts on her short journey with Harold.

What a lovely film this is. I have seen it a few times since the early eighties and it's a different experience as one gets older, you change perspective, but it's always so fine! Very typical of it's time (clothes and soundtrack) and yet a classic. Life, death, growing up in a surrounding who does not take interest in you, relevant to how many youngsters!?! Then the fact that it makes you laugh as well as (almost) cry, what else can you expect! Maybe Ruth Gordon's girlie behaviour is a bit too much, she might be quite irritating in real life, good then this is a movie. Gordon's character becomes a good inspiration for everyone who wants to keep his/her naivity through life and live an unconventional life. Enjoy!

Harold and Maude has long been a cult favorite since its release in 1971. It's Hal Ashby's quirky black comedy about a strange rich boy named Harold, played by bug-eyed Bud Cort, who is so bored he stages trick suicides to annoy his uncaring mother. Harold meets octogenarian Maude (Ruth Gordon) an eccentric who loves life. She helps Harold out of his depression and teaches him to love life again, as well as a few other things. The theme of a May-December romance was quite novel in its time. The soundtrack is by folk singer/songwriter Cat Stevens and features many of his most popular tunes. The movie is a minor film but has its own charm and an uplifting message.

"Harold and Maude" (1971) is a unique story of a romance involving death, love and life. If you want to get as much out of it as possible, there are a few things you need to keep in mind before watching:Harold and Maude revolve around... well, Harold and Maude. Harold's background has rendered him pretty lifeless, and it is not until the second part of the movie where his character starts to take off. Due to this, the beginning of the movie can feel a bit stale, but be patient.The music is typical for the 60s and 70s, which some acoustic songs playing every now and then. They are somewhat prevalent, which will be either a nuisance or a refreshment based on one's attitude towards that particular genre.Perhaps the most important fact to know beforehand is that this movie can come across as very disturbing. Harold frequently stages his own death in a multiple of ways, and although meant for comedy, they can be frightening for those who are more sensitive. The suicides take form through hanging, neck slicing (although off screen), drowning, setting himself on fire, and suicide by handgun as well as by knife.Harold and Maude also features a brief sexual relationship between two characters of very different age. Nothing is shown, only implied, but this could potentially come across as disturbing as well. If one manages to look through and appreciate these details, however, Harold and Maude is a fine comedy with both laughs and poignant questions.My personal grade: a slowly ascending 6/10. If you found this helpful, check my profile for more reviews.

reviews.review_title: If you want to sing out, sing out...
reviews.content: I don't really want to be a 'George' (Hotelgeorge) of this world and slate (or say how wonderful) the film is, but I do want to say that this film should make you think. If you don't 'get' it the first time you see it, don't then think "oh, that was bad". Watch it again and think of WHY Harold feels why he does and WHY Maude might 'lead him on'. The film is about freedom of expression and of love...very relevant in todays age. And if you think the film has 'dated badly', then you need to realise something... WHO CARES if the film looks old...IT DOESN'T MATTER!!!!!!! It's the content of the film that counts. (And for the record, the Cat Stevens soundtrack is fantastic!). It will continue to be an influential and provocative film for years and years. wado101 16, UK

If you don't fit in and you find something you discover is worth loving...go for it...and love it for all you can.  Maybe something good will come from it.  It did to Harold.  I find this film uplifting and rewarding everytime I see it.  It is a classic in a world where classic is over used for everything from Coke to 70's music.  Accept no substitutes:  this one is a real classic.  This film had it's biggest success in Minneapolis, where it ran in the mid 70's for 3 years at the old Westgate Theatre in Edina.  The theatre then closed it's doors, realizing maybe that this could never be topped.  At it's 1000th showing Ruth Gordon (Maude) visited in person. It's dark, but it's got a bright side of hope too! No thumbs...I am tired of thumbs...but this is one masterpiece of film work and feeling.

When I was younger, I can't remember how many kids wished they either were Harold, or wish they were his friend.Why? I guess because as a young adult, going through adolescence, there's such a strong feeling of isolation, of being different.They're coming into a new world - the adult world, and so many things, emotions, are either new, or take on new meanings.Harold is a 'misfit.' Even though he seems to have been born with a silver spoon in his mouth, he's lost. He's emotionally, isolated, and he deals with these feelings by separating himself further - by constantly pushing his mother's 'buttons' as she (vainly tries to introduce Harold to several young women.Harold's mother, played marvellous straight-faced by Vivian Pickles sits Harold down one day, and says to him that it's time for him to grow up. But, like most young people, Harold has to find his own way, and on that path he meets someone who does help him grow; Maude (in a performance that fits Ruth Gordon like a second-skin).Maude is all that Harold NEEDS to be. Needs to feel.With Maude as his 'teacher,' Harold has the best friend - and first love he could ever have dreamed.As the film progresses, Harold lightens up - both figuratively and literally.I can't give away the end, though, in a way, it - like life, is inevitable. But, through it, Harold is able to grow up - and learn lessons of life, love, and maturing into one's own skin.Harold Ashby makes one of the most epoch-defining (and pushing) pictures of the 1970's, with a terrific soundtrack featuring Cat Stevens, who was just beginning to emerge as a huge star of the 70's .I can't stop hearing 'IF you want to sing out, sing out' as I write this.Even though I'm older - and, hopefully wiser, this film is, if anything more life affirming to me, as someone who has lived, as it show how valuable relationships and life are - no matter what someone's age.I still would love to have a friend like Maude.

When I originally went to see this movie, I was very skeptical since I am in college and it was my mom who dragged me in to watch it.  It is surprisingly funny, although the humor is extremely morbid.  But I am all for the morbid humor!  And the soundtrack is all CAT STEVENS- and that guy has some awesome lyrics to his songs.

reviews.review_title: "The earth is my body, my head is in the stars"
reviews.content: I love this movie. It is original, hilarious and witty. Ruth Gordon and Bud Cort are wonderful together. I read that when it first came out, the relationship between Harold and Maude shocked people, but I thought it was pretty cool. This movie shows that it doesn't matter how young or old you are, love can happen anytime and with the person you least expect. One of the essential movies of the 70's.

reviews.review_title: This absurdist black-comedy examines the meaning of suicide and death through exploration of sensualism and love.
reviews.content: "There is but one truly serious philosophical problem and that is suicide." Albert CamusThis absurdist black-comedy examines the meaning of suicide and death through exploration of sensualism and love. Harold is young (20), obsessed with death, and has never really "lived" despite being extremely wealthy. Maude senses life to its fullest while having few means, ignores social norms, and is obsessed with death because of her age (79). Within the context of the absurdity of the American dream and its institutions, Harold and Maude find each other and cultivate a genuine relationship complete with the complexities and co-dependencies one might expect of any good love story. The simplicity and faithfulness of their interaction is accentuated by the visually tacit character of Cat Stevens' music.It appears that this film has been influential, both in its use of music and its style. Most notably, its legacy may be found in the work of Wes Anderson (The Royal Tenenbaums, The Darjeeling Limited).

reviews.review_title: Unique Love Story, Made Convincing By It's Two Leads. Certainly A Flawed Film, But Ultimately Uplifting, And Heart Warming.
reviews.content: It was very nearly a 6/10, but then I realized how unique or special the movie was. Somehow it manages to convince us that an 80 year old woman and a 19 year old boy, falling in love is natural and normal. The two lead actors do a wonderful job of showing us the possibility. The film is flawed, of course, in the way many new Hollywood films of the early seventies are flawed, but ultimately it is an uplifting story, humorous and memorable. And most importantly it's still fairly entertaining. The ending is a bit perplexing, but you should be satisfied.

Just finished watching Harold and Maude by Hal Ashby and this was a big surprise for me cause movies at that tim weren't so bold like this one, specially when it comes to humor...This film is about a boy and an old lady and they both live their lives as if it was their last, only that Harold (the boy) doesn't really care about his life and Maude (the old lady) really tryes to make the best out of every moment.These are two really good and odd characters that also make a good and odd friendship, they go around city stealing cars and just having the time of their lives with each other, meanwhile when Harold returns to his life with his rich and controlling mother, he realizes he'd never really experienced real life and that's why he doesn't care about it.I think the screeplay as well as the direction did a great job bringing such an odd story to life and giving a great meaning to it, I believe the message here is basic enjoy your life, take chances, be grateful for what you have, we see this in a lot of movies but never in such a creative way.There were also some sharp criticism in the humor here about social institutions, one of my favorite scenes is when Harold is about to be forced into alisting at the army and he and Maude make a plan together so he won't have to go, so you can imagine that this scene has a very smart humor. (I won't describe the scene so much so you don't get spoilers).Some of the serious parts and the drama are not so effective in my opinion, but I think it still works.I highly recommend this film, you may think some of the jokes here and there are a little outdated but I hardly disagree, this is way ahead of it's time and it's just great.I'm giving this a 8,5/10

I have read the "book"(the screen writer's thesis paper). There are bits left out of the movie that would have put even more of a spin on the plot. Maude draws smiles on the saints' statues in the church--she believes that anyone intimate with the Divine should be blissfully happy.It works on the level of ancient pre-Christain religion archetypes of the cyclical nature of life and rebirth. It gets mentioned several times in the movie. She is the Crone of the triune goddess, teaching the youth about life and love.The context of the movie must be seen as a retort to the Vietnam war, where men even younger than Harold's character were being used as mortar fodder on a daily basis. The draft was inescapable for the majority of young Americans at that time, which makes his uncle's diatrabes about the glory of Army life extremely ironic. Maude's soliloquy in the military cemetery is bittersweet. "I feel that much of world's sorrow comes from people who are this(living things), yet allow themselves to be treated as that(endless rows of tombstones in the VA cemetery)."Harold "has it all" but having and being are two different animals. Bliss is not something that can be picked up at Macy's. His mother keeps trying to fix his outsides to make the inside all right, with disatrous results for her pawns.If you look at the symbolism for the Major Arcana of a Tarot deck, you find the ground that Harold & Maude flourished in. If you take this movie too literally, you will miss a lot of the humor. This started out as a rock opera. Hal Ashby had a very wicked sense of humor. Look at the sly wit of "Being There", his last film.Unfortunately for our world one of Maude's observations still rings true "Zoos are full, prisons are overflowing--oh my, how the world still dearly loves a cage!"When Harold describes his adventures with chemistry, she gives him more excellent advice--"A lot of people enjoy being dead, but they're not, really; they're just backing away from life. Reach out take a chance; get hurt even--play as well as you can--L-I-V-E, live; otherwise you've got nothing to talk about in the locker room."When was the last time you heard a character in a movie be that direct? This is the opposite of self-absorbed. Words to live by (bad pun). It took a time, a place, and a generation to make a movie like Harold & Maude. We weren't self-absorbed, we were reaching out for understanding in a world turned upside down. If you don't get this movie, don't despair. There's Prozac, internet porn, Botox, and a volunteer army. Play it safe...
