I've never seen a midnight movie but Tommy says they showed these MidnightMovies at Midnight in the Seventies. I don't know I wasn't there. But if this is the type of disgusting film they showed I'm glad I wasn't there.All kinds of gory scenes played for fun. Black comedy is what Tommy called it. I don't get this. And I guess I'm supposed to say SPOILER but he makes love to old woman. Gross. Why couldn't they get a nice younger woman for this film? It makes no sense. All reviews say this is a good picture but I think it's not. I think people like this film because they think they supposed to, like the way Russia used to be. Dumb and gross and stupid. They shouldn't be allowed to make movies like this. I'm Todd M. and this gets no stars.

reviews.review_title: It got me through junior high.
reviews.content: This is a very unique film. For something so sickly humorous, it is surprisingly uplifting.  It's well worth seeing at least once no matter what your cinematic tastes.  The first scene is particularly brilliant.

reviews.review_title: I'd Never Seen the Whole Thing
reviews.content: Harold & Maude came on the satellite the other night and I became gradually transfixed. I'd never been a great fan of Cat Stevens but his music was perfectly fitted to the story. I'd seen bits of the movie before but not the whole thing. I'd have remembered it.Many movies of the era come across as dated and annoying but this one doesn't. It evokes emotions that are always relevant and the period elements become inconsequential.I was struck looking at the IMDb rating chart that it rates almost equally across all ages and gender. It is rare to find a movie that we "Over 50's" and youths both find great appeal in.

HAROLD AND MAUDE is certainly one of the funniest movies of all time, but is also one of the most important human stories as well. I only saw this film quite recently but it hopped straight to my number one film of all time. It is beautiful. Bud Cort is charming as Harold and Ruth Gordon - dare I say cute? As Maude. If I look like her when I'm eighty I'll be out there nicking cars and fluttering my eyelashes at policemen too! Maude wrenches Harold free from his morbid and lonely existence to show him how lush and amazing the world can be and he emerges from his experiences a happy man. This is definitely one of the films that (along with say, Fight Club, American Beauty and The Rocky Horror Picture Show) show you can be who you want to be, and you needn't let anyone oppress you. It's brilliant.

This Movie is always 'interesting' when watching it for the first time. In fact, I may be the only person who really enjoyed it a first time around. Harold and Maude is full of witty dark humor that leaves the viewer more captivated each time they watch it. There are so many 'little' things that nobody catch the first time around, probably because they're too dumbstruck by the whole basic plot line of the movie. How is a person supposed to begin laughing at the cultural humor, when they're too busy gawking at the 'issues' that Harold has and the 'way of life' that Maude presents to him and to the viewer. Then, with a second viewing, it becomes clear that these two polar opposites (in every way possible) bring out the best in each other and throw out all the rules of society.This movie deserves far more credit than it is ever given! If you don't like it the first time... watch it again! -Purple

Attending funerals probably does not fit into everyone's definition of fun, but in Hal Ashby's Harold and Maude, starring Ruth Gordon and Bud Cort, the characters do just that. Set in San Francisco Bay area in the early 70's, Harold and Maude tells the story of Harold, a friendless, troubled, rich boy who is desperate for his mother's attention. This all changes when Harold meets Maude, an unconventional older woman, who becomes his friend, love interest, and mentor. At first the film, written by Colin Higgins, struck me as being very odd. After all, the story of a 19 year old boy who repeatedly fakes suicides, drives a hearse, and who falls in love with a 79 year old eccentric woman wouldn't be considered normal by most. However, despite its unusual plot, Harold and Maude is an entertaining movie with lessons on life and living it to the fullest, friendship, and loveif you can get past the 60 year age gap between the two characters.The opening scene at first seems tragic. To the tune of Cat Stevens, Harold seemingly hangs himself in his ritzy California home. When Harold's mother discovers him, she ignores him and makes a phone call. These mock suicides, which happen a total of seven times throughout the movie (though Harold tells his psychiatrist he has done this about 15 times before), are all dismissed by Harold's mother, although they are an attempt for her attention. Harold seems to live a sheltered life, and is very quiet; his mother is not concerned with what he wants, as demonstrated in her want of Harold to join the military, or for him to get married. Cort's acting, which is characterized by little facial expression and an awkward manner contrasts with the acting of Gordon, who is boisterous, with exaggerated movements and tone of voice to portray her unusual character. The two form a friendship after meeting at a funeral; a friendship that consists of car stealing, visiting cemeteries and junk yards, spending time at Maude's train car home, and tree replanting. Most of the humor in the movie comes from wacky antics they do together. Cat Steven's "If You Want to Sing Out" is the song that Maude seems to live by, as she does whatever she wants (even if it's illegal), and becomes the theme of Harold and Maude's relationship.Interesting camera angles are used in unique ways throughout the film, adding to the films overall mood. At times, Harold adds a comical mood by staring directly into the camera, as if he and the audience are in on some inside joke, such as after he "sets himself on fire" in front of his first date. Moving shots also add to the humor, especially in the pool scene, where Harold has apparently drowned himself. After a shot of Harold, we get a shot of his mother walking to the pool. The shot follows his mother, until the audience discovers the two characters are in the same pool. Many shots focus on one aspect of an object, and then move to show the whole object, such as the front of a car or the light of a motorcycle. These odd shots add to the overall effect of this funny film.Overall, Harold and Maude is an entertaining and unconventional movie, which teens and adults alike can enjoy. While the idea of Harold and Maude's love still creeps me out, it's not enough to say the movie is bad, though it still seems unrealistic at times. The trick with Harold and Maude is to see past the unexplainable fake suicides, stunts, and nontraditional love, and take in what the movie is trying to tell you: to live life to its fullest. No matter your take on the movie, its theme of living and being yourself is something that everyone can appreciate.

"Love has no boundaries." This quote is true when it comes to describing "Harold and Maude." This movie tells the story of a death-obsessed 20-year-old and a lively 79-year- old woman. Harold (played by Bud Cort) is a boy who likes to do fake deaths and go to funerals in his free time. Maude on the other hand, loves life and can't wait till her 80th birthday. Their relationship turns from friendship to love.I would recommend "Harold and Maude" to anybody. The acting done by Ruth Gordon is unforgettable. Her spirit and liveliness in this film makes anybody watching want to be her. And Bud Cort. . . even though he doesn't speak much, his actions are memorable in many ways.Many people think that this relationship between a young man and a VERY old woman can't work. But this movie crosses the line and works well. Hal Ashby and Colin Higgins did a great job directing and producing this film. They did everything that supposedly couldn't work in a film.My Rating: 10/10, Romance/Comedy

reviews.review_title: My favorite movie of all time
reviews.content: Harold and Maude is the best movie I have ever seen.  In an age where the amount of action usually dictates the size of the crowd, it was a thrill to see a movie like this.  It is a flawless film with rich action, unbelievably natural performances, brilliant cinematography, a wonderful score by Cat Stevens, and a great and often hilarious story.  Maude's pholosphies and thoughts in this film, when though about and applied to Life, can change yours.  I have since bought the script to the stage play, the short story, and the movie itself.  Unfortunately, the soundtrack was never made available in the States, but if you have enough Cat Stevens albums eventually you'll have all the songs in the movie.

reviews.review_title: Truly a black comedy, but so were those times. . .
reviews.content:
If there was ever a movie that makes you want to fake your own suicide, this has got to be the one. But seriously...I saw this movie in an art house theater in the U district in Seattle back in '71 or '72. Being only in my mid-teens at the time, it made for compelling viewing. Then, just the other night on AMC channel, I watched it again. It's the first time I've seen it in many years, and I must say - not having seen it in quite a while - I had almost forgotten what a moving film it really is.On the surface "Harold and Maude" was, and still is, a delightfully bizarre "jet-black comedy". I still laugh at the absurd, twisted physical jokes, but... this movie also works on other levels. I must admit it is heart-piercingly uncomfortable for me to re-watch this film, namely because the troubled, directionless and apathetic Harold (Bud Cort) is such an apt symbol of what I and perhaps many others felt like during those foolish and awkward days of youth. The movie brings it all back with a roar. (Gawd, like we need to be reminded!).Also, the movie does a fantastic job of recreating the unsettling "zeitgeist" of that era. History lesson: The late sixties/early seventies were such a troubled time; for those of you who don't remember, the U.S. was involved in a very unpopular war, and very little of the patriotic, support-the-troops fervor that you see nowadays existed back then. You don't have to look very deeply in this movie to see and/or feel the anti-war, anti-military, and anti-establishment sentiments. This movie aptly captures that "spirit of the times" (again, yeah - like I wanna' be reminded!). I know growing up is always difficult, but it was truly difficult to grow up during those times when so much of what you had been taught to value, trust and respect was constantly being questioned, desecrated, revealed as sham and so forth. That's not to say that this movie doesn't project its own positive vibes. It's just that, in some respects, the movie opens up old wounds.So yes, this was (and still is) truly an anti-establishment picture if there ever was one. Just the whole premise of a 20-year old young man dating (and bedding, and proposing marriage to..) an eighty-year old woman simply flies in the face of all that is holy and sacred to just about anyone, anywhere on the planet! But that's what makes this movie great, and well worth watching. It dares to be different, but is smart enough to do so with a pleasant eccentric charm rather than vulgar excess. And, the hippie-days Cat Stevens music, playing at just the right times, is wonderful icing on the cake.
Some of the humor I particularly liked: I enjoyed Harold's visits to his one-armed Army officer uncle, who fills him with tales of military glory whilst in the background, totally off camera, you can hear the pounding cadence of a firing squad, marching a prisoner out to be shot. I also liked the "this fills me with revulsion" talk from the priest, replete with references to Maude's "sagging breasts" and "flabby buttocks". (Alone worth the price of admission!).Anyway, I love this movie; it works for me on so many levels. It is indeed a black comedy - but then again so was my youth, which took place about this time. It's only taken me 30 years to figure it out.

reviews.review_title: A movie that fell from Heaven.
reviews.content: I wanted to hug this movie. I couldn't belive how much this movie had an impact on me. Everything about it makes it sad,funny,and brilliant. This is one cult classic not to be missed. If this movie does not move you in anyway I don't think I would like to know you! Everyone who has not seen HAROLD AND MAUDE, see it! ****.

Harold and Maude is a profoundly spiritual film. It is a story of a death-obsessed 22-year-old neurotic Harold and an eccentric, touchingly childish 80-year-old "sorceress" Maude. The whole movie is seen through the prism of Harold's internal struggles. He is hungry for life, yet is mortified by what he perceives its utter lack of meaning. He wants sympathy, affection and attention, and tries to attain all of them by means of committing fake suicides -- but all for naught: Harold's ice-cold and haughty mother ignores him, ignores him as a sovereign human being, while treating him as a domesticated pet. At a certain juncture, Harold meets a highly non-conformist and easy-going old lady, Maude. She is "sent" to poor Harold by the dint of fate in order to rescue his soul from the utter morbidity within which it had sunk. The relationship which develops between them is beautifully portrayed in the film. Maude is conjured up into existence by Harold's "guardian angel." She heals him. She cures him. She shares with him her internal sources of vitality. She teaches him the science of happiness, the most difficult science to master. She gives her life to Harold. The film leaves you with a lingering bitter-sweet feeling. Harold and Maude is a philosophical elegy, a film of lasting value, a movie the importance of which is only bound to increase. Wonderful work of art.

One of the very few movies I would see more than once.  I've seen it well over 10 times because it makes me laugh and fills my heart every time.  If you like Cat Stevens it's worth it for the musik.  If you ever need a fresh look at life and /or love,   This is it. I save this movet for very special friends, like a very special cognac. You deserve to see this at least in your life

A film that tells us the value of enjoying life and fulfilling one's promise.Harold's pallor is sickly, almost dead. Then he meets Maude and is revitalised. Their relationship is touching and genuine.This should bear repeated looks7/10

reviews.review_title: If you want to sing out, sing out!
reviews.content: If you want to sing out, sing out! I think that's the name of one of the songs in the movie, which is one of my greatest favorites ever. This movie is a rather weird comedy about love and freedom. It seems to say that you can be weird, if you want to, and it is all right.

reviews.review_title: Great blend of satire, farce, and pathos with a great score to boot.
reviews.content: Some of Cat Stevens' best tunes highlight this marvelous serio-comedy of a romance between a young neurotic and an old philosopher.  Ruth Gordon hits the pinnacle of her illustrious career with this take-no-prisoners performance. Bud Cort, fresh off Brewster McCloud and M*A*S*H seemed to be well on his way to establishing himself as one of cinema's top comic artists (If anyone knows what derailed him, please let me know).  An excellent supporting cast blends absurdity and reality with great aplomb.

This is a wonderful and life-affirming film, that appeals to social outcasts as myself.  I first saw this about 12 years ago, when I was suffering from "tortured young man" syndrome.  I completely identified with the morbid and hilarious Harold.  The film taught me that there really is a different way to see things, even in the pit of despair.  Life is what you make of it. The Cat Stevens soundtrack is terrific as well.  It's too bad that he left the world of music to dedicate his life to Islam.  A truly gifted songwriter.  This movie made me a tremendous fan of Bud Cort.

I've seen Harold and Maude, finally ! Not that I really wanted to see it. For me Harold and Maude was one of those movie you always notice on the video store's shelves but never want to rent. You rent The Abyss instead or something like that.. I knew it had a good reputation but I always had the feeling that a movie with Harold and Maude as a title could only be boring. Why rent that when you can go with Predator? And for some reason I always got confused between Harold and Maude and Miss Daisy and her driver. Maybe because they both have old people in them. Well this week-end, around a campfire, my parents said that when they were going out, in the seventies, they saw Harold and Maude and thought it was great. Great for the time or great in general they did not know. So I rented it to find out.So ? So even if I don't think Harold and Maude is a masterpiece it clearly has the charm of the best films of that period of greatness in American cinema : the early seventies. I always thought that the main strength of movies like Scarecrow, Panic in needle park, The Graduate and, now, Harold and Maude was the blend of vitality and melancholy we can see in the wonderful way those movies are shot. The story of Harold and Maude is quite simple : a young man and an old lady fall in love and they share the best moments of their lives in a celebration of life. Of course the characters and situations are, for the most, original but I would not think it is as groundbreaking as some people might say. In my opinion, the similarities with The Graduate are too many to be purely coincidential. I like Cats Stevens when I hear him on the radio but I don't necessarily want to listen to his best-of while watching a movie. Maybe the production team of Harold and Maude took their influence in the use of Paul Simon's songs in The Graduate but in that movie we didn't have to listen to the Sound of Silence every other scene.The acting in Harold and Maude is top notch : I especially liked the actress playing Harold's mother. She's something of a caricature but we believe it anyway. In fact I think the movie succeed the most in the fake-suicide scenes. That's where the movie is the most cynical and funny. When Harold rediscover life, tough, I think the director is a bit clumsy (when Harold is blowing bubbles for instance). Sometimes it's a bit embarrassing really... As for the last sequence I think it sums up the message of the movie : that Youth will prevails even in Death... or fake-death ! 7.5/10.

This is by far, my favorite movie.  It's quirky and kooky.  It's got a great soundtrack.  But aside from being funny, well-directed, and well-acted, Harold and Maude shows us how to L - I - V - E !  I know I've had much more to talk about in the locker room since I saw this movie!

reviews.review_title: "'Cause there's a million things to be..."
reviews.content: For years, I'd heard numerous good things about this low-budget cult comedy, but somehow I never ran across it. Well, last night I did, and I'm pleased to say that it truly is a superbly nuanced, beautiful piece of cinema. You probably wouldn't think a film could work as a black comedy, a biting social satire, and a sweet, sincere romance all at once, but Harold and Maude does--brilliantly.Harold Chasen (Bud Cort) is a repressed young man whose main outlets are attending funerals and staging of elaborate pseudo-suicides, much to the annoyance of his controlling rich-bitch mother (Vivian Pickles). At one of these funerals, he meets Maude (Ruth Gordon), a wise, free-spirited old woman who careens around California in "borrowed" cars. What follows is one of the funniest and most touching pairings in screen history, exploring love, death, and the importance of living.All around, a witty, intelligent, wonderful picture, from the sparkling performances to the seamlessly executed material. I'm not much of a Cat Stevens fan (records like "Wild World" make my teeth grind), but the soundtrack here is truly great. In fact, the sanitized, get-along world could stand to learn something from Gordon's delightful heroine: Existing is not the same as Living, and not living is a fate far worse than death. Thanks, Maude.

This movie is definitely one of my all time favourites, it's intelligent, witty, surprising, simply brilliant. There's not much more I can say: You can't tell this movie, you have to see it.However, it does require an open mind to enjoy Harold and Maude,  it's definitely not of the MTV-Generation, and maybe people who thought "Starship Troopers" was patriotic do better to avoid it.

(Spoilers) Ruth Gordon, Bud Cort, and Vivian Pickles are all great in the ahead-of-its-time Harold And Maude.  Gordon plays an apparent Holocaust survivor who has decided to live life to the fullest and by her rules only, and does a very good job of playing the free spirit.  Cort has some hysterical scenes as Harold, mainly playing off his mother's (Pickles) non-reactions to his fake suicides, and then to the shock of his blind dates.  This movie stays grounded the whole way through, and never goes for cheap and sappy sentiment, surprising me quite frankly.  The funniest scene in the movie is toward the end, when Harold has finally expressed his love for Maude.  You think everything is going to be big smiles and lush music, but instead we get a priest (Eric Christmas) articulating what is no doubt in the back of everyone's mind.  Big twist of an ending, too.  You really didn't see this kind of filmmaking again until the late 1990's.  Good stuff.

"Harold and Maude" is one of those rare movies that never grows old with me. I've seen it a number of times and appreciate something different about it each time. Cat Stevens' "Footsteps in the Dark" CD contains most of the songs from this wonderful film. "Harold and Maude" is an uplifting, inspiring film about living life to the fullest whether you are really at the beginning of your journey or near the end. I can't think of a more beautiful message.

It's not the movie I don't get, I don't get why so many people love it. The age difference between the leads is a clever conceit and the movie is mildly amusing, but it is also ponderous and heavy-handed. The Cat Stevens soundtrack destroys any subtlety. The life and death themes are pat and detract from the black comedy. I don't recall too many serious conversations about life in the much funnier Kind Hearts and Coronets or Dr. Strangelove. I'm left to believe that the less discerning are attracted by the anti-authority, anti-military, anti-religion, anti-wealth tone. It's worth a watch, but don't expect more than some fitful chuckles and be prepared to sit through some lessons on the beauty of life.

Harold And Maude is a classic, or at least a cult classic. Whatever it is, I liked it a lot! This movie has charm and wit and humor and a delicious cynicism about things. I love movies that make you think. That make you want to change your perspective about how things should be.A 20 something guy is obsessed with death. He attends funerals and pretends to commit suicide in front of his mother. At a funeral, he meets a 79 plus woman They spend a lot of time together. He announces that he is to going to marry her. But she may have other plans.From a very sharp and smartly written screenplay by Colin Higgins, Harold And Maude fell into the hands of director Hal Ashby, who adds a real charm and sweetness to these seemingly eccentric characters. Ashby plays the satirical humor with a light touch that makes it palatable.Actors Bud Cort and Ruth Gordon are exceptional in their respective roles as Harold And Maude.
Swiss Army Man (2016) makes Harold and Maud (1971) look almost . . . Normal. I gave Harold & Maud a 5 rating because one person's weird can be another person's inspiration.

Harold may never be a great banjo player, but I could watch him dance forever. In fact, I don't think I could be happy with anyone else. These days he might be diagnosed with Asperger's syndrome. I mean, why do we have tohave facial expressions? He might also be labelled a Goth for his whitemakeup and fondness for driving a hearse to strangers' funerals. But he'sonly following a family tradition - his mother dresses in dark colours and their mansion is done up like the Tower of London. Ruth Gordon shows that youcan go on being pretty and feminine as long as you like. I love the way sheplays with her long hair. Yes, the movie is of its time: rescuing trees, poking fun at the establishment and the military. A brief sight of the number tatooed on Maude's arm goes some way to explain her determination to celebrate life.Love is the answer agrees this old hippy. xxxxxx

A film about a depressed lonely boy searching for meaning in life. He is ignored by his parents and tries to get their attention through his attempted suicides, which I might say are very humorous scenes. He is eccentric, drives a hearse, and is infatuated with death. Its not until he meets Maude that he becomes interested in life. Maude is an 80 year old woman, about 50 years his senior, and they fall in love. A very interesting relationship, intriguing characters that we really start caring about. We follow them on their journey, as they teach each other about life, and we learn from them. Love in any form can be beautiful......just as long as you are lucky enough to find it. Mickey and Maude are that lucky......you must see this 70's classic if you haven't already.

reviews.review_title: When this came out many thought I looked like him, caused me some problems
reviews.content: When this movie was out in second view 1980, I was working as a USO DJ, and we gave out tickets to movies. Bud Cort is a little over 10yrs my Sr, but aged slow back then. Bunch of us (DJ / Vets) went to the Movie, and when we came out several people asked me for an Autograph, but I signed my DJ call sign due to thought it was me they wanted the Autograph. I had a Hight/Tight Military Haircut back then. Even the Other DJ's with me didn't see the resemblance at the time, and figured because coming out of a Dark Theatre into Southern CA Sun made them see things. It took 2 years until friends stopped harassing's me that my Girl Friend was over 60 yrs my Sr. Which the Lady I was Dating at the time almost broke up with me, due to they also kidded that she carried her age well.The Interesting thing of this movie, is a lot of people tried a lot of Harold & Maude's Tricks, some were Hospitalized. I was a USN/USMC Corpsman back then (The DJ was volunteer) and we saw a couple patients due to the Movie. Couple of us (Corpsmen) went due to being recommended by the "Psych" staff at the Hospital to see it.The other thing of this Movie, is really showed how some acted back in the late 70s-early 80s. Probably due to it was a time many of the Movies, TV shows were famous for quotes, and repeatable things to do.I really wanted that Converted Hearst, to drive to work (Hospital). I would have of course painted it Field Vehicle "Green" and with proper Red Crosses.

Harold & Maude is my favorite all time film. The story revolves around a bored, lonely, and disenfrachised young man who is obsessed with death-so much so that he stages mock suicides for his mother's (with whom he lives alone) "amusement" and attends funerals for people he has never met. Harold has many eccentricities, but deep down, he just wants to be loved. At one of the funerals he meets Maude, a free-spirited optimist who doesn't see the crime in stealing cars (or trees) because they are materialist and sentimental objects "..here today, gone tomorrow, so don't stay attached to things...". They fall in love and not long after, Harold decides he wants to marry Maude. The only problem is, he's 20-ish years old, and she's turning 80 next week. Both Harold and Maude are two of the best characters the screen has ever seen; Bud Cort and Ruth Gordon both do great jobs in bringing them to life, and the black comedy that this film is rife with is absolutely brilliant. Hal Ashby's directorial skills are on full display, and the cinematography is flat out great (the picnic in the graveyard, need I say more?). A truly amazing, great, earnest movie with scenes that will make you both double over in laughter and wipe away the tears. 10 out of 10, this movie has no flaws. Put this at the top of your must-see list if you haven't seen it, and at the top of your see-it-again list if you have. I recommend watching it at least once every few months. -Kenneth

reviews.review_title: Wonderfully quirky without over doing it
reviews.content: I am a teenager and my mother sat me down to watch this movie. I loved it. It was strange and ever so slightly outdated but its message and storyline was incredible. I feel in love with both characters and intrigue by their relationship.It was definitely worth watching and it should be more popular than it is.This will always be one of my favorites.The only downside to this movie was when I watched it my mother didn't tell me about the ending at all, so when it happened I burst out crying because it came as such a shock.

reviews.review_title: Black comedy/ Love story. The two working unusually well together.
reviews.content: Love this movie.Gives you that pure sense of pride for doing what you want, that few movies do. Follows the story of young Harold and old, old Maude falling in love with roughly 60 years between them.Sound gross? I can guarantee you, it's one of the sweetest movies I've ever seen, as well an incredible jet black comedy.Hilarious, insightful and touching (not to mention the great Cat Stevens score.)Watch it.

reviews.review_title: Watching this movie required effort & attentiveness
reviews.content: I watched "Harold & Maude" on video with high expectations, but could never quite adjust to its erratic rhythms.  I found the Cat Stevens sound track intrusive and constantly had to adjust the volume between the loud songs and the barely audible dialogue.  Though I admired Harold's quirkiness (and his self-expression through automobiles), his pallid face looked more like 14 than 20, which made his mother's meddling in his social life even more surreal.  The character of Maude was amusing & great at talking her way out of trouble, but definitely strange.  The 1970's clothes & decor date the movie strongly and the characters seemed more British than American in their accents & sensibilities, which was disconcerting.  I just couldn't get into this movie beyond an occasional scene or two.  The abrupt scene changes and random characters took so much effort to figure out that I never relaxed enough to enjoy it.  "Harold & Maude" felt more like work or obscure philosophizing than entertainment.

My Mother loved this movie and so do a lot of older baby boom women I know. However as a baby boomer man when I finally it saw recently I was struck by the fact that to me Harold was obliviously gay and not interested in women except for Maude in a very weird non sexual grandmother way. True they sleep together but I suspect that was just some non erotic hugging and keeping each other warm. Harold is like Sheldon in the Big Bang Theory a man child that doesn't know he is gay or even what that is about just that he is not interested in women in a hetero way.The movie however is fun and quirky, but please keep the romance out of the way this is really about friendship at any age not love/lust way. It is worth seeing as an adventure of 2 people who need and like each other- nothing more

I just watched Harold and Maude again on HBO. It had been years. I was about Harold's age when the movie came out. Then, the movie represented my generation from both Harold's and Maude's perspectives. The rebellion of Harold, the optimism of Maude. As a 50-something Baby Boomer now looking back and watching the movie from this perspective, it is such an affirmation of life. A reminder that no matter what, you can always find something new. A reason to live life beyond the mundane, beyond what is expected. One of the best films ever made, not because it is great literature, but because it is so alive and human. It cuts to the chase. It doesn't need a lot of words or intellectual chatter. It just "is," and that is what makes it so wonderful.

Ah! What a perfect, beautiful little movie. A dark comedy, that is not for everybody, but for those who are game...it's bliss. Death-obsessed young Harold meets up with much-older Maude, and his whole outlook on life is transformed in just a few remarkable days. Probable? Probably not, but this is the movies, so who cares?Bud Cort as the moon-faced Harold, gives a gem of a performance. Ruth Gordon, as Maude, well...can you think of a better performance of hers? Vivian Pickles as Harold's snooty, oblivious mother is also memorable. Extremely sharp writing by Colin Higgins, with some really wonderful lines. Terrific location photography in Northern California also adds to the general ambiance, as do Cat Steven's spectacular songs. It's no wonder this has become a cult movie classic. Unforgettable.

reviews.review_title: An uplifting comedy, that proves that love has no boundaries
reviews.content: This movie is my all-time favorite, and that is saying a lot (since I teach film classes and see a lot of movies).   I've seen it over 100 times.   It tells the uplifting story of the unusual friendship that develops between 20 year old Harold and the life-affirming 79 year old Maude, as they cope with the "big issues" of life.   It also is a very funny social satire of the times in which it was made, lampooning repressive institutions like the Army, the police, the church and psychiatry.   And it contains a great score by Cat Stevens.  When I was younger, the film appealed to me (and many others) because of the many ways Harold and Maude rebel against stifling conformity, eventually demonstrating that love has no boundaries.   Even now, in middle age, I find the film relevant, and I hope to grow up to be Maude!

It's basically a comedy which turns into a tragedy (towards the end), and this very odd couple is indeed funny, though the black humour is a bit excessive in some scenes. Director Hal Ashby had a subtle sense of humour, for the most part, but Harold's obsession with death becomes repetitive and predictable.I've read some reviews here, which find the relationship between these two "moving", LOL. (6/10)

Words can't begin to describe my affection for this movie. I have put off seeing it until now just because I had the wrong impression of what this movie was about. Harold the kid who is bored with life and everyone around him. Yes he likes to fake suicide and attend funerals. Maude is the person everyone would like to become or at least I would. She enjoys life and takes what she wants from it with no guilt. They meet because they both like to attend strangers funerals and it leads to a great friendship (romance I suppose). It's what everyone movie is trying to achieve but few do it truly is a classic in my book.

reviews.review_title: One of the hundred films I'd want on a desert island
reviews.content: I watch this film about three or four times a year. It's one of those late 60's early 70's films that just to seem to have fun with irreverent subjects - only one car crash! To see Bud Cort again in Dogma was crazy! My God, have we all aged that much?? The music by the former Cat Stevens adds a sweetness to the film that is sadly lacking in many films today. I was one of those kids - like Harold - who felt left out because of what I thought were weird thoughts. This film helps us not to take ourselves to seriously. The only scene I felt was not really needed was the obligatory "bedroom" scene - not that I was offended in any way - it just seemed unnecessary.

reviews.review_title: "The Greatest Love Story of All Time"
reviews.content: I watched Harold and Maude based solely on it's mention in Something About Mary, so i didn't have high hopes. I was surprised to find it a movie far ahead of it's time. For a movie made in 1971, Harold and Maude manages to intelligently communicate with a sophisticated teen audience, and pulls of an otherwise (before i saw this movie) implausible concept, probably largely due to the clever plot of the novel.Bud Cort controls the character superbly as does Ruth Gordon, and they make roles that could be overdone and hackneyed as smoothly as warm butter. The entire movie is believable and moving, and deeply affecting.

reviews.review_title: Everything you've heard about this wonderful film is TRUE!!
reviews.content: Hal Ashby's masterpiece still resonates with charm, warmth, absurdity and one of the best soundtracks in movie history. If you've ever questioned your reason for living, if you desire a transcendental film experience....or if you just want to laugh, DO NOT miss 'Harold and Maude'. There's a very good reason why this film is on AFI's Top 100 list of American comedies. You'll love this treasure.

reviews.review_title: Worth watching but definitely of its time
reviews.content: A classic and everyone interested in American films of the 70's should check it out. Some funny moments but mostly weird for the sake of being weird. Dated but does a timeless quality. The Cat Stevens songs on the soundtrack are terrific.

This is a great film with some really hilarious scenes (i.e., the faked suicide scenes and the modified sports car). However, it deals with those sticky, basic questions concerning what make makes us happy and how to live life to its fullest. Ruth Gordon exhibits a spontaneous drive for life that is a perfect counterpoint for the boy's hesitance to engage in his life.In reviewing it, it's probably more relevant now I'm closer to Ruth Gordon's age than the boys. It's also a cool period piece (for those of you who lived through that period) with music by Cat Stevens and the "crazy" popular in the 70s. An enjoyable film with just a bit of an edge.

reviews.review_title: NOT AS HILARIOUS AS EVERYONE SAYS
reviews.content: I just saw this film today in film and video class, and boy did I wish that the teacher would just shut it off.  I don't know why he even put it on.  He gave us the option of watching this film, Dr. Strangelove, some other film from a million years ago, and Men in Black.  Personally, I would've rather watched Men in Black.  The jokes in Harold and Maude are just not funny. The kid Harold was just annoying.  His suicides made me feel like telling him, "hey buddy, stop pretending to kill yourself, you're an idiot".  And he looked so sickly. I guess that's what the director wanted, to have a sickly looking kid play a character with bad psychological problems.  But man, this guy, his whole look, he looks like a young Bill Gates, and I don't know why, but whenever I see Bill Gates, I really get annoyed just by the way he looks.  Do you ever get that feeling, you get really irritated just by someone's physical appearance? Ya, Harold did it for me.  I was screaming for this film to be turned off after the first 10 minutes.  I got so bored of this film that I stayed bent over on my desk showing plumber's crack for the whole class period in hopes that a hall messenger would walk by and get a hairy surprise.  That's the only thing that kept me up through the film: the anticipation of seeing the disgusted look on an unsuspecting hall messenger's face.  If I wasn't ballsy enough to show my a$$ to people, then I would've been in hell for 85 minutes.  So the moral of the story is:watch Harold and Maude if you feel like showing some plumber's crack for 85 minutes straight.

reviews.review_title: still holds up well after 1/4 century
reviews.content: Despite its '60's sensibilities and flower-power overtones, this is an outrageously funny (and touching) movie that still holds its own after nearly 3 decades. When it was first released by Paramount during the Christmas season of 1971, it was met with scathing reviews--and largely ignored. It was quickly discovered  by college students though, and continues to be a cult classic--particularly among college students. A surprising number of people (including myself) list this among their favorite movies, if not their *favorite* movie...how many other movies released so long ago can make such a claim? It's certainly different: 20 year old death-obsessed boy meets and falls in love with new-age octogenarian. It's not tasteless though. This film looks beyond the surface and there is great beauty in their doomed relationship. Cort and Gordon here complete each other--each has something the other desperately needs. Many of the lines are priceless--and immensely quotable. This is probably part of the reason it's achieved staying power. The dialogue is still as fresh and witty as it was in 1971--and Cort's fake suicides are truly hilarious. So is Vivian Pickles as his mother. Things wrap up a little too quickly--and the ending is ambiguous--but I think this was intended. Like a great painting, its meaning is open to interpretation, and asks more questions than it answers. A movie that begs to be seen more than once to fully appreciate. The underrated Bud Cort and late Ruth Gordon have an on-screen chemistry that transcends their ages--and just blows you away.

This movie is critically acclaimed, but it it terrible.  I've never been so disappointed in a film in my entire life.  To call this a black-comedy is like calling water wine.  I don't understand how it can be called a comedy--it seriously is not funny at all.  I'm not just being spiteful or exaggerating; this movie is simply not a comedy of any kind. If one had to classify it, it would be a drama I guess, but the film really isn't a drama either.  I personally would classify it as "wish you didn't spend 90 minutes of your life being submitted to hippy propaganda".  The only person who would even remotely like this film is a tree hugger or a wannabe hippy, and even then I would think that they were lying to justify their lifestyle. My recommendation is if someone tells you to see this movie, never take any movie advice from that person again, because they have extremely poor taste in movies.

reviews.review_title: "Give back the head, woman! We'll have no trouble!"
reviews.content: One of the greatest films ever made!  Charles Tyner's performance as Uncle Victor is the epitome of how absurd right-wing conservatives truly are. Vivian Pickles should've been nominated for an Oscar for her priceless portrayal of Harold's mother.   Ruth Gordon and Bud Cort are perfect as Harold and Maude.  You can't help but feel a little sorry for Tom Skerritt's police officer.  He just can't win!  Possession of a stolen shovel, indeed! Anyone who can't appreciate this film has a boiled turnip for a brain.

reviews.review_title: Loved this as a teen, dislike it as a senior
reviews.content: Portrayal of existential nihilism was all the rage in 1970, when this movie was made. It seemed awesome when I saw it as a teenager, but right now on a rewatch I found it pretentious and annoying.It is NOT funny to have unlicensed, senile old women stealing cars (including police vehicles) and driving recklessly, thereby endangering others. It is NOT courageous to encourage a young man to carpe diem but then chicken out of one's own life just because one has hit 80. It is also a stereotype to portray wealthy people, including their children, as unhappy -- most are quite content, and millions would be happy to trade places with them.

This movie was made four years after "The Graduate," which has now become much more popular and infamous than this film. The subject matter is similar. Like that film, "Harold and Maude" focuses on a disaffected young man from a wealthy family who develops a relationship with an older woman. One scene in particular--where Harold is shown in a pool, underwater, in one of his fake suicides--seems directly reminiscent of a scene in "The Graduate." Yet here is where the similarities seem to end.While the relationship between Hoffman's Benjamin and Anne Bancroft's Mrs. Robinson is purely sexual, Harold actually falls in love with Ruth Gordon's lively, optimistic Maude, whose passion and vitality are the antithesis of everything in Harold's sheltered, spoiled life. As a result, while "The Graduate" seems more of an exploration of the cynical, disillusioned elements of the late 60s, "Harold and Maude" rejects these ideas in favor of a more poignant, heartfelt story. Harold's romantic/sexual attachment to Maude is incidental; it is more important that Harold learns how to live life day by day, to embrace different experiences, and, most importantly, to love.And while this message today may seem dated, it's not one we hear nearly often enough today. The movie also transcends its message with memorable, likable characters: Harold, a rich, lonely twenty-year-old who frequents funerals and feels that fake suicides are the only way he can get the attention of his inattentive, self-absorbed mother, and Maude, a vital, lively octogenarian who "borrows" cars, poses nude for ice sculptures, and smokes bongs in her spare time. Their attachment to one another is genuine, and in spite of the "ick" factor of their age difference you find yourself rooting for the characters.Harold's faked suicide attempts can be a little disturbing for the faint of heart, but if you can get through the gore of some they turn out to be some of the funniest scenes in the movie. This is one of my favorites. With its unique characters and upbeat message, it is a movie that is about being happy and loving life, something that many films of subsequent decades seem to have lost sight of.

Harold and Maude: A Wild Ride; A Must SeeHarold and Maude, directed by Hal Ashby and released in December 1971, is a quirky story about two unexpected lovers. The two wacky main characters, Harold (Bud Cort), a 19 year old boy is obsessed with faking his own suicide and Maude (Ruth Gordon) a 79 year old woman who enjoys stealing cars and joyfully riding around, but never forgets that in just a small time she'll be 80. When the two meet at a funeral, an unusual friendship results. While the plot line is somewhat unbelievable, the eccentric characters and the fantastic filmmaker's craft make for a phenomenal movie. The bizarre characters keep the viewer on edge the entire movie. The scene in which the viewers meet Harold, he has "hung" himself. Soon we see that he is not really dead, but because the viewers were momentarily horrified by the fact that a movie would open with such a scene, an immediate love for Harold ensues. It soon becomes clear that he is just trying to gets his mother to pay him some attention and show that she loves him, and with this he has already stolen the hearts of the audience. And then there is Maude. How could one not love a 79 year old woman who enjoys stealing cars and lives so carefree? We first meet Maude eating an apple as she watches a funeral. Soon after, we see her steal her first car and we love her for her "seize the day" lifestyle, because who wouldn't want to live like that? The viewer continually is shown subtle hints to her past life, which allows the viewer to appreciate this attitude all the more. The terrific craft used in making this film allows the absurd plot to almost be sensible. The cut from Harold "shooting" himself, to yet another funeral scene creates a momentary gasp from the audience. They can easily predict that this isn't his funeral (as he has already faked his own suicide twice and been to several funerals), but for that split second they have to wonder what if? These moments in the movie deepen the emotional connection the viewer has with the characters. Every time Harold fakes a suicide, the cinematography allows the viewer to think, just for a moment and although they know it is not true, that Harold may have actually killed himself. The directors and editors use this to their advantage until the very last scene, making a remarkably edited film. The eccentric, but lovable characters and the terrific art used in making the film allows the viewer to completely forget that the plot is absolutely ridiculous. Because we have an immediate love for the characters, it doesn't bother us that Harold is always attempting completely unbelievable suicides and because of the editing, we almost believe them. Maude's attitude toward life makes us love her and we are completely entertained by all the ridiculous stuff she does and as the viewer gets more and more subtle hints as to what her past as consisted of, our respect and love just keeps growing. This movie is a must see, if not for the fall-out-of-your-seat laughter, than for the artful editing.

reviews.review_title: This is a REAL love story!
reviews.content: We saw this movie when it first came out and loved it!  I had never encountered this type of humor before and wasn't comfortable with my own reactions.  I was laughing when I 'should' have felt compassion.  "I don't believe this!!" kept going through my mind.  We should all be so fortunate as to experience love that truly comes from the heart and beyond.

Harold and Maude let me say was one of the funniest yet sentimental movies I have seen in quite some time. I watched this film in my Philosophy class to discuss the theory of existentialism. The first scene really takes one off guard and has angelic music playing while someone (whose face is withheld till the end of the scene) is lighting candles. Then without warning the scene cuts to Harold dangling by his neck in a noose in the living room; the last thing I suspected. As if that wouldn't take you off guard enough, his mother walks into the room and is completely amused with Harold's "childish games" and continues to talk with him as he dangling from the rope as if he is just sitting in the chair next to her. It is this kind of witty dark humor that fills every scene of this film. That first scene really sets the tone for the whole movie. I most definitely enjoyed Maude just as well and would love to spend a day with her crazy and carefree logic. The contrast seen between Harold and Maude displays two sides to the way an existentialist's view life; either the "life has no meaning, I'm not going to take part" or "life has no meaning, I'm going to make up my own rules as I go along." Two both very different extremes of this theory. I will also admit that Harold and Maude are probably the cutest together which make them hilarious. Overall, I think this film gave me some of my own inspiration for a view on life, but will definitely have to watch again to absorb everything after relaying the movie to the theory of existentialism.

reviews.review_title: I've seen this film more times than any other.
reviews.content: This is a film about life, shown through the eyes of two people focused on death.  Harold, who faked death because he didn't know how to live, and Maude who knew better than most how to live life fully, yet made her plans to die.  And, it is a tragic love story, doomed to fail from the start. And, it is a protest to war.  From it I learned how to focus on what's important, and not sweat the small stuff.  A very motivational film.

reviews.review_title: A Splendid film on life, and HOW to live it. Cat Stevens provides a great Soundtrack. A Film with a Lesson!
reviews.content: If you've ever thought how wonderful life is, you must see this movie. Truly a feel good movie that leaves you with something every time you see it.  The wonderful lesson it gives is to enjoy life, live to the fullest, and don't live in death.  You have to see the subtleties to enjoy the humor, but when you see it, it is extremely funny!  This is a comedy, a romance, a drama, and a Wonderful movie.  I recommend to all, unless you are going to give it a bad vote.

reviews.review_title: Love, death, sex, and coming-of-age angst set off by humor
reviews.content: The movie handles the Great Topics of life with such compassion and humor that the audience doesn't realize that the movie is not really a comedy... until it's too late and the viewers are drawn into the April-December romance.  Spectacular acting adds to the rich flow of the story.  And, Cat Stevens's voice slides us along through the transitions.  It's the ultimate 60's coming of age movie, but it shows well in the 00's, too.  Thank goodness its now out in DVD!

This is one of the best films I have ever seen. Not only is it hilarious, clever, and oddly romantic, but it has a strong message to LIVE LIFE. I wish more movies like this were out there. Everyone should see this film! EVERYONE!!

A wonderful wonderful film, I have never seen another movie that so effectively made me think!  See it often and tell everyone about it!  You will not be disappointed.  If I ever end up stranded on a desert island, a copy of Harold and Maude will be enough for me!

Perhaps the best party movie ever?Perhaps, indeed!This is one of those movies that should never stop being watched.  It's perfect.  It fits anytime.  Good for groups of people to watch together, good for anyone to watch alone.  It commands ones' attention.  I've probably seen this fourteen times, each time I was in a different mood.  When I needed cheering up, it cheered me up.  When I was on some sort of sugar high, It calmed me down and (however cheesy it sounds) made me think about life a little more.The acting is astounding, and I had a crush on Bud Cort after seeing this, (knowing he was MUCH older that I am), and I always wondered why he never did anything mainstream again.  The old lady who played Maude was terrific too.  I can't imagine Maude being anyone else.One of the best movies ever.My grade: A+

Watched it because of the hype, greatly disappointed. Harold is an extremely creepy manboy, a brat obsessed with death. Neither he or Maud are likeable and every other minute a Cat Stevens song comes on. A very un-funny comedy to me. He probably ends up as a serial killer after the movie ends.

I ran into this movie on cable one night late last year.  I actually only got to see the last 20 minutes of it, but it was enough to make me run out and find it on DVD.  I think I must've gone to 5 stores when I finally found it.  There was only one copy there and I was so happy it was mine.  I had always heard of this movie over the years.  One of those "cult classics" I hadn't ever seen but was always curious about.  I can't imagine liking a film more.  I've never seen two more interesting characters than Harold and Maude.  It's amazing to see the changes Harold goes through over the course of one week in his life.  You can literally watch the color come into his face the more he gets to know Maude, and gets to know how good life can be. But Maude is really my favorite.  She looks at the world in a way most people don't.  She stops to appreciate what we take for granted.  She is truly grateful for life and takes advantage of it.  Bud Cort and Ruth Gordon give amazing performances.  Their chemistry on screen has rarely been matched.  I'm so glad I finally got around to seeing this beautiful movie. It ranks as one of my all time favorites and always moves me everytime I see it.  It makes me want to wake each morning, and greet the day with the breath of fire.  :-)  Thanks, Maude.

reviews.review_title: Not for everyone, but a true classic
reviews.content:
Harold is one messed-up teenager.  He's obsessed with death, and drives a hearse. His mom isn't helping, she ignores him except to throw "normal" girls at him.  Then he meets Maude, who is not your usual grandma.  She teaches him to enjoy life in ways he's never imagined before.
The Cat Stevens soundtrack is a highlight of this film.
No violence, no nudity or explicit sex, no foul language, no special effects, but this movie definitely tries to shock. Don't show it to kids. Watch it yourself before showing it to teenagers.Some of Maude's explanations for the ways she behaves, though, really did make me stop and think.SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS below this line SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERSThis movie shows a number of scenes where Harold fakes his own suicide, which his mom brushes off. Some viewers will find this disturbing.
A key plot feature is the romance between 14-year-old Harold and 70-something-year-old Maude. The sexual aspect of that makes it onto the screen in a single short scene with them smoking in bed afterward, decorously covered by a sheet. Again, some viewers will find this disturbing (as do some of the characters.)The third time I saw this movie I finally noticed the single brief flash of a concentration camp number tattoo on Maude's arm. It dramatically changed the tone of the rest of the movie for me, putting Maude into a much stronger context. She's definitely weird, but I could see how she got that way.

reviews.review_title: A Movie I Will Always Love and Cherish
reviews.content: Harold and Maude is one of those movies that touches people in so many ways. The setting was one (I grew up in the Bay Area so the scenery is familiar), the music of Cat Stevens is another, and mostly it is the wonderful work of Ruth Gordon. If a movie was ever made for someone..this one was made for her or maybe she was made for the movie.The comments the movie makes on life and death are so true. It leaves you feeling sad yet also happy. Amazingly I do not own this movie yet, but will get it soon to add to my collection. I urge you to do so too.Funny, sad, touching and even controversial...a memorable film that is timeless and simply lovely!

Harold and Maude is one of my all time favorite films. I've seen it at least 50 times. Before I was married, I would use the film to screen prospective dates. If a girl I was dating didn't like it, she wasn't for me. To appreciate this film, one needs to transcend the darker and more eccentric moments of the story to understand its profound affirmation of life. It is a story of a young man who, for all intents and purposes, is dead to the world. His encounter with an 80-year-old woman, in the twilight of her life, teaches him a lesson in how to grow out of his morbid, narcissistic fascination with death and learn to live life to the fullest. It is also hilariously funny at times, especially Harold's faked suicide attempts that he performs to send his overbearing mother into hysterics. Yet the comedy acts as a medium by which to open the viewer enough to feel the deeper emotional movements in the latter half of the film, when Maude swings the door of the world wide open for Harold. Ironically he comes to love and live more fully when confronted with the genuine experience of the fragility of life.

reviews.review_title: "Always looking for the new experience" - Maude
reviews.content: It's rather easy for me to get a wee bit hokey when talking about this film, but the sentiments are real.To me, it's about a young Harold, voicing his desperation for love and freedom through 'fake' suicides, who meets a lively Maude, who's anthem is individuality at all costs.The endearing dialogue, the dead-on soundtrack (courtesy of Cat Stevens), and the inimitable and unforgettable performances by Bud Cort, Ruth Gordon, Vivian Pickes and the rest of the cast make for a charming film that just might change your life !"If you want to sing out, sing out! And if you want to be free, be free!"Harold And Maude is definitely an experience to be had !

reviews.review_title: Charming, subtle comedy in a very original film.
reviews.content: I would rank this movie my favorite black comedy of all time, and one of my favorite love stories. Please realize that the black comedy of "Harold and Maude" is not meant to be slapstick or laughing-out-loud hilarious, but the humor is there. The late 60s/early 70s style doesn't date the movie, so much as place it in a certain context (perhaps it's a comment on the infamous "generation gap" of the 60s?) and add a certain style and flair. I agree that Cat Steven's soundtrack doesn't blend seamlessly into the film, but after several viewings, it's come to seem really appropriate to me.This movie is eccentric and charming, like the characters involved. There are some great touches -- Harold investigating Maude's sculpture, Maude's smell-o-rama machine, and of course the opening scene...

This is probably my favorite movie of all time. I'm naturally attracted to dark comedy, and when you add up the stellar acting, the fantastic script, as well as Cat Steven's music... well, this is a winner. I can't count the number of times I've seen it, yet I still cry at the end! It's a powerful movie about overcoming obstacles and pitfalls (with flair, and a sense of humor), and learning to love yourself and others. All of us 'eccentric folk' out there can appreciate this movie from beginning to end.

reviews.review_title: An eccentric, quirky story of discovering life and love...
reviews.content: Bored and desperate for love and attention, young Harold dwells in his own misery and tries to bring everyone around him down along with him. Obsessed with death, his morbid personality is a reflection of his dissociation with the world around him. His rich mother simultaneously ignores him and smothers him, leaving Harold starved for affection and longing to join his deceased father, yet lacking the conviction to actually end his miserable existence.Enter Maude, a totally over-the-top senior citizen who is loopy, lovable, and overflowing with life. Played magnificently by the late, great Ruth Gordon, Maude is a true eccentric with an insatiable lust for life, and Harold is immediately drawn to her. They form a unique bond and develop a relationship which changes Harold profoundly.This movie stands the test of time. While the cars and clothes may be dated, the characters express feeling and emotion which does not change over time. And while all this sounds very deep and dramatic, this is actually one of the funniest movies I've ever seen. You really have to see this one for yourself, and I'm happy to hear that new generations of film lovers are continuing to enjoy this "cult" favorite.

This film, though unappreciated for its true theme, is still a classic today. Colin Higgins wrote the screenplay as an undergraduate--as a lark, and was flatly told it was a flop. It was finally shot during the height of the Vietnam War. When it appeared, it was received by the "Woodstock" generation as an anti-war film. The romance between Harold and Maude is incidental (but definitely the break point for viewers). One must look beneath to see Higgin's focus. If you enjoy it, count yourself lucky that you can see deep meaning where others see disgust. Ruth Gordon said she enjoyed making this film more than all her others.

reviews.review_title: One of the best comedies ever made
reviews.content: One of the best comedies ever made. The beginning sequence is wonderful, even after I've seen it over and over. The use of Cat Stevens' music is perfect. And the acting is letter-perfect, especially Ruth Gordon. She is unique, but also a type that we recognize. A great film.

reviews.review_title: In a League of it's Own Way Beyond Classic! It's Phenomenal!
reviews.content: I watched Harold and Maude when it came out in the 70's and I will NEVER forget it for every worthwhile reason! The personalities of those two were loaded and bursting at the seams with a uniqueness so special you would blessed to meet just one person that original in a lifetime and they found each other. Good people to me and hilarious! You must see it! Your life can only be made better for it! Truly!

Harold is a young man who is obsessed with death. He stages fake suicides, drives a hearse and goes to lots of funerals. Maude, on the other hand, is an older woman (almost 80 years old) who is enchanted by life. She lives life at its fullest and she sees death with different eyes.
This is a movie about love, friendship and knowledge exchange. While Maude shows Harold different ways to see and live life, she also learns a lot from him. It's an incredibly deep movie but its approach is light and funny.

In some ways, it mirrored my own experiences as a child (without the benefit of a great deal of money or a 79-year-old girlfriend). I was completely enthralled with this film. I resisted watching it for a long time - I will resist anything someone else insists I must watch. SPOILER ALERT The only part that bothered me was the ending: at a time when the two could be peacefully celebrating their last few hours together, he panics and she spends the last hours of her life with strangers poking tubes and needles into her. Therein lies the tragedy.

This is possibly my favorite film of all time. I love it and I'm shocked and pleased to see that this many years after it opened people are still talking about it. Concerning the numbers on Maude's arm....if you watch closely, I think Bud Cort plays it in such a way that you SEE that Harold DOES know what they are. The message of loving life and the importance of expressing yourself artistically is so strongly put forward in this film without being saccharine or didactic. I love her urging him to drink oatstraw tea (very good for you). Also, the laughs never go away. I've seen it many times and his mother answering the dating questionnaire, the dates themselves, the military one-armed uncle, and the line about him co-mingling with the withered sagging "buttocks" still crack me up.

reviews.review_title: Harold and Maude as a ruler for dating
reviews.content: I have watched this movie in an attempt to see why everyone likes it and alas....Nada! I do however use this movie in my dating life and as a rule if the girl in questions voices her "love" of this movie, I generally go the other way. I have yet to meet many emotionally "balanced" fans of this flick. But...yeah, for it anyway it does help me weed out the manic depressives in my life. Anyway, more power to those that find it entertaining. I also find those same H and M fans tend to like pedantic junk like Prairie Home Companion also. Again, it is a useless horrible movie. Anyway, feel free to comment me back on your opinion I'd love to hear a witty retort.

Funniest Movie of the 1970'sThe movie Harold and Maude written by Colin Higgins and directed by Hal Ashby is one of my all-time favorite movies. Made in '71, it is a hilarious movie for teenagers on up. The humor is dark and at times gruesome, but viewers will find it hard not to laugh out loud. The movie stars Bud Cort as Harold and Ruth Gordon as Maude. Harold, (Bud Cort) is a nineteen year old man who is depressed and seeks a strange sort of attention from his mother. He fakes his death multiple times. For pleasure, Harold attends funerals, where he unexpectedly runs into an old woman, Maude (Ruth Gordon), who also goes to funerals for fun. The pair have many adventures together in the San Francisco Bay area of California, where Maude ultimately brings Harold out of his shell. Because of it's talented acting, excellent cinematography and unconventional story line, Harold and Maude is one of my favorite movies. Both Bud Cort and Ruth Gordon are very skilled actors in their roles of Harold and Maud. In the beginning, Harold never smiles, has a stark white face and bulging eyes. From his facial expressions alone, the viewer can tell Harold is a morbid kid. His faking suicides are also very believable. It takes an up-close camera shots to tell he's not dead in many of the cases. Although beyond the beginning it looks like Harold doesn't change his expressions a whole lot, he shows quick flashes of deep, surprising emotions. When he and Maude are flying around the corners in Maude's stolen blue car, Harold looks scared. This is surprising because he seems so fearless. These quick facial signs show he wants to live after all. Also, in multiple places, his face shows a deep admiration and love for Maude. This also is strange because she is almost eighty while he is nineteen. Ruth Gordon portrays Maude's fearless sense of adventure and will to lives everyday to the fullest, very well. She even sings remarkably well for an eighty year old. Without the skilled acting of Bud Cort and Ruth Gordon as Harold and Maude, the movie would not be the classic that it is. The cinematography is extremely off-the-wall making it so viewers can't look away. In the beginning, there is a shot of a mirror streaked with blood and Harold lying below soaked in blood. This is the first shot that makes the viewers go, "Wow! Did I really see that?" Also, Harold is seen at funerals mourning with people he doesn't know for a complete stranger. Nevertheless, the shots show he looks to be one of the saddest people there. When his mother first brings a possible marriage candidate for Harold, he does a strange sort of ritual by the pool. The next scene is "Harold" engulfed in flames. Following this, the girl runs out screaming while Harold casually walks in from the back and smiles at the camera. Another scene that is remarkable crafty is a reflection of Harold's military uncle saluting with his right arm missing. Viewers be warned never to to look away for you will be sure to miss a crafty shot. The movie follows a strong theme that everything is impermanent, so no one should ever get too attached. Maude especially lives by this code. She is constantly stealing other people's cars. When Harold tells her he thinks people are getting upset, she says, "I'm merely acting as a gentle reminder don't get attached to things." Another one of Maud's quotes is, "Try something new each day, after all life doesn't last forever." Maude lives moment by moment and gets Harold to start enjoying life too. The ultimate letting go for Harold comes at the end of the movie when Maude does something very surprising, (although there are clues if you look for them) that forces Harold to let go of the intense love he has for her. Letting go and living life moment by moment is a lifelong lesson presented in Harold and Maude. Harold and Maude is an excellent movie that combines skilled acting, crafty cinematography and a unique story line. Though people don't usually turn to a 1970's movie for entertainment, this is sure to please. Besides serving a comical purpose, Harold and Maude defies all stereotypes and shows that it takes adventure and enthusiasm to open the heart of those suffering from depression.

reviews.review_title: Over look of Harold and Maude
reviews.content: Harold & Maude directed by Hal Ashby and the written by Colin Higgins tells the story of the young Harold (Bud Cort) and Maude the spontaneous and elderly woman played by Ruth Gordon. The story starts with a confused 19 year old Harold and his various acts of fake suicides to catch his mother's attention with an overall obsession with death. As with Maude however, a 79 year old woman who seems spontaneous, doing whatever she pleases, seems to have a view of all people should live to 80 and that should be it. Whereas the characters seem to be a bit unique in their own ways the plot seems to carry that throughout the film. The use of narrative elements, film maker's craft, and acting allows for this film to be truly phenomenal.             The narrative elements in this film produce a stable structure for the rest of the film to build off. The movie itself takes place in an area around the San Francisco Bay; this can be seen through various screen shots of the bay and the cliffs overlooking the ocean. The viewer can see that much of Harold and Maude's time is spent in Maude's home composed of a Pullman car when Harold enters her house for the first time. The conflict can be seen through mostly his mother. Harold's mother, Mrs. Chasen, is obviously the antagonist in the story she does not seem to pay her son enough attention and in doing so he fakes suicide to get some. Eventually she gets sick of his unusual acts and tells him it's "time now to put away childish thingstime for you to get married." Whereas the conflict seems to be his mother trying to get him to marry the plot seems to be him continuing to commit fake suicides and falling in love with Maude. Even with all of these very unusual events going on I was able to pull an overall theme out from all the controversy. Maude says that she "likes to watch things growcycle of life." Both Maude and Harold seem to have fascinations with death so it would only seem right that one theme would be about the cycle of life. The film maker's craft adds to the content to make the movie one worth watching. Editing seems to be one element that stood out the most to me in this film. The director did a great job cutting in and out of shots to make things appear to happen that did not. We can see Harold create this mock immolation of his own death. To the viewer it almost seems evident that it is actually Harold, but as the scene continues Harold comes into the picture and its impressive how the director is able to confuse not only the other characters in the scene but the viewer as well. SPOILER ALERT Another example of this in genius editing by the director is another fake suicide we see Harold attempt when he runs his car off the ledge it does not seem reasonable that Harold lived through it, but we are again fooled by this amazing editing skills by the director. Another element that the director does a good job showing is the realism of the suicides. It is obvious to me that he put a lot of time into making these scene seem so real. We see Harold cut his arm off and blood comes out it looks so real and the viewer is fooled just like the date in the scene. The realism of the fake deaths put on by Harold is so well composed by the director it helps this movie in being as incredible as it is. The acting is also unique and played very well within the film. All of Harold's acts of faking suicide are very well played out. The first scene when he pretends to commit suicide by hanging himself could not have been played any better. I was almost appalled by the start of the story thinking for sure that this character was already dead. The believability of Harold's fake deaths' is amazing it was hard for me at times not to think that Harold was dead even after the second and third times of seeing him fake them. When he is pretending to be drowned in the pool this is just another example of how well the acting in this scene is. When we meet Maude we are able to see how well Ruth Gordon plays her part. Maude is sitting eating an apple during a funeral of someone she did not know either. Ruth Gordon does a good job at perceiving a character that seems to know what she wants and a very spontaneous personality. Not only are the narrative elements, filmmaker craft, and acting spectacular in this film it does however shed a bit of humor. The scene that takes place between these two intervals is shocking, very unexpected, and unconventional. What makes a great movie great? There is a wide spectrum of answers to this question, such as the film's characters, the actors, soundtrack, the director's craft, and even the sometimes-subtle lessons that can be learned from viewing the film. In the 1971 film Harold and Maude, directed by Hal Ashby, all of these aspects are each well deserving of attention, and when all are combined react in such away that creates a very colorful and fun viewing experience. Harold Chasen (played by BudCort) is a 19-year old boy who lives with his wealthy middle-aged mother, and spends his time attending random funerals and feigning suicide. As his activities would suggest, Harold has a sort of morbid disposition, which does not bode well with this mother. As Harold struggles to escape the lifestyle his mother believes is right for him, he meets Marjorie "Maude" Chardin, played by Ruth Gordon, is a very active 79 year-old woman who like Harold enjoys attending the funerals of strangers. Although they share that similarity, Maude lives a lifestyle in which she essentially lives everyday like it's her last. As the story progresses and the relationship between Maude and Harold grows we also see a change in Harold's attitude, as he has adapted Maude's way of seeing things. Many aspects of the film contribute tomaking watching this movie such a great experience. First of all, you have the contrast between characters Harold and Maude. When we first meet Harold nearly everything about him is symbolic for death; the hearse he drives around, often visiting random funerals, and faking his own suicide. Maude, on the other hand, can be seen as a symbol for actually living life, which can be seen through her everyday activities, like stealing cars, playing music, being a nude model, and something to do with a hookah. The contrast between the two characters,along with the changes we see in Harold (becomes interested in things other than death, and becomes less pale) create some element of comedy, and is overall a fun thing to see. Secondly, the film's soundtrack doeswonders to establish the 'feel' of a scene. For instance, during amontage in which we see Maude and Harold participating in various activities (i.e. dancing on a hilltop) we hear the song "If you want to sing out, sing out", of which the lyrics go "Well, if you want to singout sing out/And if you want to be free, be free 'Cause there's amillion things to be/ You know that there are". Another example is when Harold is pretending to have drowned in his pool, and we hear classical music as the camera pans out from a closeup of his face. Perhaps the most important aspect of the film though, the director's craft involved with developing the film. An example of clever authors craft is the progression of Harold's skin tone throughout the film. As we see the story progress and him become more active with Maude, we also see Harold's complexion become darker, a result of him spending more time "living". This physical change is symbolic for Harold's shift in mental attitude. In addition to many subtle messages that can be found, like the example just given, is the overall theme of the film, be who you want to be.Overall I would say that this is a great movie, especially from a time of which the attitudes, opinions, etc. from the characters matched that of the counterculture at the time. The soundtrack (by Cat Stevens) accompanies the story snugly and provides something fun and easy to listen to, while the constant activity and body language amongst the characters keeps it appealing to the eye. Looking deeper than the physical aspects of the film lies the artistic beauty that can be found in the contrasts of two opposite people.
